STBLKeyStringList.Text: As compensation for the time and effort {0.SimFirstName} spent on authenticating the {1.ObjectName}, they've sent {M0.him}{F0.her} {2.Money}.

Hearing of {0.SimFirstName}'s archaeological renown, the Artifacts Association is sending over some artifacts and is requesting help in identifying their origins.\n\nThey are promising a huge financial incentive in return for {0.SimFirstName}'s help.
{0.SimFirstName} has successfully extracted the following element:\n{2.String}
{0.SimFirstName} has blessed {1.SimName} and turned {M1.him}{F1.her} into a skeleton! A surprise, to be sure, but a welcome one.
{0.SimFirstName} has blessed {1.SimName} with a bounty of Simoleons! That's one way to spread the wealth.
{0.SimFirstName} has blessed {1.SimName} with some new relationships! {M1.His}{F1.Her} friend network just got a mystical bump.
Ancient Joy has spread to {0.SimFirstName}. It is almost as contagious as laughter or yawns.
The Curse of the Ancients has spread to {0.SimFirstName}!
{0.SimFirstName} has cursed {1.SimName} with one of the Curse of the Ancients! It may be best to stay away from {M1.him}{F1.her} for a while.
{0.SimFirstName} has cursed {1.SimName}, marking them for death! It may only be a matter of time now before {M1.he}{F1.she} receives a grim visit.
{0.SimFirstName} has cursed {1.SimName} with a personal cloud, sure to sour {M1.his}{F1.her} day!
{0.SimFirstName} has cursed {1.SimName} to see the ghostly images of Selvadoradian food. It may not be the most dangerous curse, but it's certainly distracting.
(From Dispelling a Curse of the Ancients)
{0.SimFirstName} has dispelled a Curse of the Ancients and received a Blessing of the Ancients!
(From Dispelling a Curse of Greedy Needs)
{0.SimFirstName} has dispelled a Curse of Greedy Needs and received the Blessing of Self-Care.
{0.SimFirstName} has dispelled Marked For Death. Now {M0.he}{F0.she} is blessed with a Skeletal form.
(From Dispelling Curse of the Personal Rain Cloud)

{0.SimFirstName} has pushed through all the dreariness a Personal Rain Cloud Curse could throw at {M0.him}{F0.her}.

The curse has been dispelled!

{0.SimFirstName} now has {M0.his}{F0.her} own personal ball of sunshine following {M0.him}{F0.her} around because of a Blessing of Personal Sun.
A bursting gut has helped {0.SimFirstName} dispel the Food Mirage Curse.\n\n{0.SimFirstName} received the Blessing of Glorious Tastes. Everything tastes better, even week old cafeteria food.
(From Being Struck By A Stressful Cloud)
The Artifact Council regrets to inform you that they identified this artifact as a reproduction. Unfortunately, it is virtually worthless and has no scientific significance.
The Artifact Council is pleased to inform you that they have verified this artifact as a genuine Omiscan antiquity!
(From Eating a Berry from the Wild Tree of Emotions)
While excavating in archaeological site, {0.SimFirstName} found:\n{2.String}

Welcome to the jungle, {0.SimFirstName}. Some handy adventure items have been added to your inventory as part of your rental package.\n\nIf you plan on exploring the Belomisia Jungle you should first stop by the Puerto Llamante Marketplace and pick up more gear.

What an incredible combination of flavors! Now that {0.SimFirstName} has eaten {1.ObjectName}, {M0.he}{F0.she} can now make it at home whenever {M0.he}{F0.she} wants! Though, how tasty it is depends upon {M0.his}{F0.her} Homestyle Cooking skill.

What an incredible combination of flavors! Now that {0.SimFirstName} has drunk {1.ObjectName}, {M0.he}{F0.she} can now make it at home whenever {M0.he}{F0.she} wants! Though, how tasty it is depends upon {M0.his}{F0.her} Mixology skill.
What a unique flavor: woodsy, yet bitter! Now that {0.SimFirstName} has had {1.ObjectName}, {M0.he}{F0.she} can now make it on the Tea Maker at any time.
(From Distracting Bees with Guzmania Pollenis Flower)
(From Distracting Bats with Plasma Bat Bait)
(From Skillfully Evading a Plasma Bat Attack)
(From Neutralizing Flies with Drake's Fire Quencher)
(From Evading Spiders with Dr. Parker's Repellent)
(From Escaping a Bee Attack Using Insect Repellent)
(From Defending Against Lightning Bugs with Insulation Powder)
(From Skillfully Evading a Lightning Bug Attack)
(From Evading Spiders with Dr. Parker's Repellent)
(From Encountering a Jaguar in the Jungle)
{0.SimFirstName} wasn't able to fight off the poisoning and it has progressed and gotten worse. Might want to do something about that soon.
{0.SimFirstName} was successfully able to overcome being poisoned and is feeling much better.
(From Being in the Partially Excavated Temple)
(From Being in the Temple of Abundance)
{0.SimFirstName} has been imbued with the Blessing of the Ancients.\n\nThis joy is infectious and can spread to others that {0.SimFirstName} comes in contact with!
{0.SimFirstName} has been blessed with Glorious Tastes.\n\nEvery dish is delighting {M0.his}{F0.her} tastebuds. Even poorly prepared dishes have more redeeming qualities.
{0.SimFirstName} has received the Blessing of Self-Care.\n\n{M0.His}{F0.Her} needs won't be as needy for the time being. This is going to be great for productivity.
{0.SimFirstName} has been blessed with a Personal Sun.\n\nThis warm source of positive energy will brighten {0.SimFirstName}'s day.
{0.SimFirstName} has bypassed the temple's defenses and the gate has opened! {0.SimFirstName} can now venture further into the Temple to find what rewards await...
{0.SimFirstName} thought this trigger might open the temple gate, but instead {M0.he}{F0.she} was ambushed by a mystical force that frightened {M0.him}{F0.her} half to death!
{0.SimFirstName} had a good feeling about activating this trigger, but {M0.he}{F0.she} was totally wrong. The temple punished {M0.him}{F0.her} with a hair-raising scare!
{0.SimFirstName} definitely did not activate the correct trigger. Those temple defenses are terrifying! {0.SimFirstName} nearly soiled {M0.his}{F0.her} clothes from that one!
{0.SimFirstName} just got bone dusted from activating the temple defenses! What the heck even is bone dust?
{0.SimFirstName} activated the temple defenses, and now has a mouthful of bone dust.
This isn't sand...it's...bone dust? Ew. {0.SimFirstName} is paying for activating the temple's defenses!
{0.SimFirstName} is getting burned from activating the temple defenses!
Is it hot in here? YES! Because {0.SimFirstName} is on fire from triggering the temple's defenses!
{0.SimFirstName} activated the temple's defenses and is now on fire!

{0.SimFirstName} just triggered the temple's defenses, and now things are feeling downhill from here. {M0.He}{F0.She} could try some of those berries from that one tree...that could turn things around.
{0.SimFirstName} is having just a miserable vacation! Activating the temple's defenses is really screwing with {M0.his}{F0.her} mood.
This vacation blows! Somehow the temple defenses really affected {0.SimFirstName} and has put a damper on {M0.his}{F0.her} experience in the jungle.
{0.SimFirstName} was looking for a way to unlock the gate, but instead found a ravenous appetite! It seems like the temple is punishing {M0.him}{F0.her} for {M0.his}{F0.her} transgressions.
The temple is punishing {0.SimFirstName} by making {M0.him}{F0.her} sooo hungry. Too bad there are only skeletons walking around here. Nothing with any meat on it.
{0.SimFirstName} activated an ancient defense, and now some mystical force has made {0.SimFirstName} super hungry. So hungry {M0.he}{F0.she} could eat a capybara!

What's this? A poison dart sticking out of {0.SimFirstName}? {M0.He}{F0.She} definitely did not activate the right trigger and the temple defenses punished {M0.him}{F0.her} for {M0.his}{F0.her} mistake!
The poison dart sticking out of {0.SimFirstName}'s neck means {M0.he}{F0.she} activated the wrong trigger. Hopefully that woozy feeling will pass soon!
OUCH! {0.SimFirstName} was trying to find a way to get through the gate but accidentally triggered an ancient defense. Now {M0.he}{F0.she} has a poison dart in the neck!

While attempting to dismantle the temple's defenses, {0.SimFirstName} could've sworn {M0.he}{F0.she} saw something appear out of thin air...was it real? Was it just {M0.his}{F0.her} imagination? The uncertainty is making {0.SimFirstName} anxious!
While attempting to dismantle some ancient defenses, {0.SimFirstName} angered the spirits of the Temple. Now {0.SimFirstName} is seeing things and is super paranoid!
{0.SimFirstName} accidentally activated some defenses guarding the temple, and is now haunted by visions, making {M0.him}{F0.her} quite restless.
{0.SimFirstName} has a glimpse of a mystical vision and is overcome by the feeling that {M0.he}{F0.she} is utterly alone in this world.

Wow. Just...*sniffle*...why? Why does {0.SimFirstName} feel so...*sniff*...alone? No friends? Family hates {M0.him}{F0.her}? Dog died? Oh. {M0.He}{F0.She} activated an ancient temple defense.\n\n...that other stuff sucks too, though.

Wow. Things just got real for {0.SimFirstName}. When {M0.he}{F0.she} saw that weird ancient magic, it somehow brought back memories of all the Sims that abandoned {M0.him}{F0.her} in life, and now feels so alone.
(From Donating to the Madre Cosecha Statue)
{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest!\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} took an Artifact and some Adventure Gear and put them in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.

{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest and the Omiscan gods have bestowed a blessing upon {M0.him}{F0.her}.\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} took an Artifact and some Adventure Gear and put them in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.

{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest, but the Omiscan gods were angered by {M0.his}{F0.her} transgression and placed a curse on {M0.him}{F0.her}.\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} took an Artifact and some Adventure Gear and put them in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.
{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest!\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} took an Artifact, some Adventure Gear, and a Mystical Relic and put them in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.
{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest!\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} gained some Simoleons and put some Adventure Gear in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.

{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest and the Omiscan gods have bestowed a blessing upon {M0.him}{F0.her}.\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} gained some Simoleons and put some Adventure Gear in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.

{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest, but the Omiscan gods were angered by {M0.his}{F0.her} transgression and placed a curse on {M0.him}{F0.her}.\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} gained some Simoleons and put some Adventure Gear in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.
{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest!\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} gained some Simoleons and put some Adventure Gear and a Mystical Relic in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.
{0.SimFirstName} found the ultimate treasure of the temple! {M0.He}{F0.She} should take a look around for other discoveries before leaving.

{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest and the Omiscan gods have bestowed a blessing upon {M0.him}{F0.her}.\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} gained some Simoleons and put some Treasure and an Artifact in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.

{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest and the Omiscan gods have bestowed a blessing upon {M0.him}{F0.her}.\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} gained some Simoleons and put some Treasure and Adventure Gear in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.

{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest!\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} gained some Simoleons, took some Treasure, an Artifact, and a Mystical Relic and put them in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.

{0.SimFirstName} found some wondrous items in the Treasure Chest!\n\n{M0.He}{F0.She} gained some Simoleons and took some Treasure, a Mystical Relic, and some Adventure Gear and put them in {M0.his}{F0.her} inventory.

{0.SimFirstName} is now an expert in the field of Archaeology. The secrets of the Omiscan civilization jump up to reveal themselves to {0.SimFirstName}.

Trait Earned: Museum Patron
{0.SimFirstName} can now donate items to The Simsonian Museum. {0.SimFirstName} also enjoys {M0.his}{F0.her} time in museums more than other Sims.
This Sim wants to understand Archaeology.

{M0.He}{F0.She} came, {M0.he}{F0.she} saw, {M0.he}{F0.she} conquered. {0.SimFirstName} has fought through the Jungle's natural dangers and solved the mysteries of ancient temples. Treasure and bragging rights are {M0.his}{F0.hers}.

Trait Earned: Treasure Hunter
{0.SimFirstName} will occasionally find additional treasure and relics in treasure chests.
This Sim wants to explore the jungle!
(From Reaching a High Point in the Jungle)
(From Being Near the Omiscan Royal Baths)
This will boost the speed at which your Sim gains Archaeology Skill while in a Club Gathering.
This will boost the speed at which your Sim gains Selvadoradian Culture Skill while in a Club Gathering
Genius is never appreciated in its own time.
The sharing of knowledge is its own reward.
Surprisingly, everything lectured about was super interesting!
Study of the root influences are important for art and culture.
The mysteries of the past truly are fascinating.
Fascinating. Records indicating the artifact is both genuine...and really old.
Hidden within all that rock and dirt was the possibility of finding history!
Kids these days don't know what true joy is. But the Ancients, they knew joy. {0.SimFirstName} is now experiencing a bit of that.
There was something mystically delicious about that meal.
The tastebud party has started. All food is more flavorful. Perhaps {0.SimFirstName} can even stomach airplane food right now.
{0.SimFirstName} has figured out how to deal. {M0.His}{F0.Her} needs are not as needy right now.
My own personal ball of sunshine brightening my day.
That collection was simply marvelous. An example like that helps {0.SimFirstName} focus on completing {M0.his}{F0.her} next task.
{0.SimFirstName} feels electricity in the air gathering around {M0.him}{F0.her}. An electrical shock is inevitable.
Reading a book really helps make the most out of all the peace and quiet.
Eating these berries imbued a sense of confidence in {0.SimFirstName}.
A rush of energy swelled in {0.SimFirstName} as {M0.he}{F0.she} ate these berries.
Romance is in the air! Eating these berries made {0.SimFirstName} super flirty.
{0.SimFirstName} became as sharp and focused as a machete after eating these berries.
Despite not washing the berries before eating them, they've made {0.SimFirstName} rather happy!
The nutrients in these berries provided {0.SimFirstName} with a healthy dose of inspiration.
Playtime! Eating these berries made {0.SimFirstName} want to be playful!
The local flavor profile was a bit too much. {0.SimFirstName} was not able to finish the whole serving. This is an acquired taste. Try raising Selvadoradian Culture Skill.
Normal bee stings hurt, but bee stings from the jungle are beyond painful!
Being a plasma source for bats is not cool. Not cool at all.
Bugs trying to cook you? Dousing yourself in water or learning more of the culture could've prevented being simmered.
With Fitness Skills like this, Sims can easily avoid danger.
Purchasing gear at the marketplace before setting foot in the jungle helped stave off a minor disaster. Money well spent!
It's a good thing {0.SimFirstName} was wearing that insect repellent otherwise things could have gotten real.
Learning from the locals has prevented some potentially nasty consequences!
Evading dangers using logical reasoning puts to use all that book-reading time!
Could've used spider repellent. Could've outsmarted the spiders using logic. Coulda woulda shoulda.
They say inspiration can be found anywhere, but it's a shock to find so much in a plain white mug.
Avoiding a scorpion attack is rather thrilling!
It feels good to out-think the jungle wildlife!
Seeing such adorable, hurt creatures pains Sims deep inside.
Who would have guessed such a peaceful herbivore could have such a nasty bite?
It feels so nice to help a creature that can't help itself!
That jaguar almost spotted {0.SimFirstName}. It'll be a while before {M0.his}{F0.her} heart stops pounding.
{0.SimFirstName} is going to be picking thorns out of {M0.his}{F0.her} side for hours!
Whoa, that totem nearly caught {0.SimFirstName} on fire! {M0.He}{F0.She} can still feel the heat!
No one's going to believe that {0.SimFirstName} encountered such a huge alien creature in the jungle!
That creature was so tiny...can it really survive on its own in the scary jungle?
It would have been so scientifically significant to watch that strange egg hatch. {0.SimFirstName} totally missed out.
So many precious mementoes of {0.SimFirstName}'s adventures are gone forever!
Ugh, if only {0.SimFirstName} wasn't so clumsy, {M0.he}{F0.she} wouldn't have lost that precious bag!
{0.SimFirstName} unfortunately encountered some rather sharp claws from some rather irritated bats.
Who knew that a simple plant could make such a terrifying noise?
A strange encounter with a wild Sim in the jungle leaves one's heart pounding!
A fabulous find in the jungle always puts a smile on one's face!
It seemed like such a good idea to fish that bag out of the quicksand. If only {0.SimFirstName} had the skills!
It's hard to not wonder if something could have been done for that suffering sloth.
Tripping over one's feet when trying to impress some jungle sloths is pretty embarrassing.
Is there anything more joyful than walking amongst a group of peaceful herbivores?
The memory of that winking herbivore is keeping {0.SimFirstName} in stitches for hours!
It's going to take a long time to wash this much mud off...
Nothing like a nest of spiders dropping on one's head to ruin your day!
What did {0.SimFirstName} think would happen, tearing through the brambles with bare hands? They're not bear hands after all. At least the scratches aren't too deep. Next time, try a machete!
Something isn't right. This icky feeling could either go away on its own or get worse. Only time will tell. Maybe acquiring an antidote would be safest?
{0.SimFirstName} was almost poisoned but {M0.his}{F0.her} body naturally resisted. The poison was flushed out! Thank goodness!
Seriously, I better speak to a Selvadoradian local for an antidote or buy one online. Otherwise, this is going to end poorly... and soon...
Poison is coursing through {0.SimFirstName}'s veins. Better find an antidote quickly! Surely someone from Selvadorada knows where {M0.he}{F0.she} can get one. Maybe search online?
Standing at the top of a beautiful vista makes you see the whole world in a new light.
Reaching new heights makes one feel they can accomplish anything!
Just being near these natural pools puts a spring in one's step!
Uncovering this secret area makes one feel they can accomplish anything!
Something about being in the wilderness, with this beautiful waterfall...really gets a Sim in the mood for romance!
The extra skeletal help is creeping {0.SimFirstName} out. It is hard to relax while listening to all those bones clacking.
Watching a set of bones work has motivated {0.SimFirstName}, who will gain extra skill while around this temporary skeleton help!

{0.SimFirstName} has been blessed with a temporary transformation into a being of bones. With less to worry about while in this skeletal form, {M0.he}{F0.she} may be able to get a few extra things done!
A humerus joke like that is bound tibia delight.
Being in this Temple unlocks the full potential of a Sim's Archaeology Skill!
Being in this Temple unlocks the full potential of a Sim's Gardening Skill!
{0.SimFirstName} figured out the ancient puzzle and now gets to keep going deeper in the temple!
Being caught off guard keeps Sims anxiously on their toes.
Even a vampire can get startled almost out of their skin!
Everything is just going wrong on this vacation. Could it get any worse?
Whew! {0.SimFirstName} made a mistake when trying to disarm the temple's defenses, but got away unscathed. Need to be more cautious next time!
Seeing things that may or may not be real can keep Sims from nodding off any time soon.
Nothing sadder than feeling like there's no one there for you. Ever.
This statue exudes confidence. If Madre Cosecha could found and build up Selvadorada, then {0.SimFirstName} can tackle anything this jungle throws at {M0.him}{F0.her}.
Madre Cosecha accepted your humble donation and has dispelled the curse.
{0.SimFirstName}'s vast knowledge in the field of Archaeology gives rise to a confident strut whenever visiting a museum.
The self-satisfaction of donating something to a museum...
Who needs to uncover rare gems and treasure when I've already found that brilliant sparkle in your eyes.
The ancients have cursed {0.SimFirstName} with uncontrollable sneezing. {F0.She}{M0.He} needs to avoid touching friends, and cook up a Remedy of the Ancients before this spreads too far.
The ancients have cursed {0.SimFirstName}, who seems to have come down with a bad case of narcolepsy. These yawns are very contagious, so cook a Remedy of the Ancients before the slumber spreads.
The ancients have cursed {0.SimFirstName}, who can no LONGER control the VOLUME of {M0.HIS}{F0.HER} voice. Cook up a Remedy of the Ancients before everyone goes deaf or gets infected.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel angry. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel bored. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel confident. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel dazed. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel embarrassed. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel energized. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel flirty. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel focused. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel happy. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel inspired. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel playful. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel sad. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel stressed. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
That jolt from the Personal Shocking Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel stressed. Counter the curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
The Curse of the Emotional Cloud is causing {0.SimFirstName} to feel uncomfortable. Counter this curse or visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha to dispel it.
This curse is causing random drops in all of your needs. Get your needs into an overall excellent state to shrug off the effects!
This curse is causing all of your needs to quickly decay. Get your needs into an overall excellent state to shrug off the effects.
This curse is causing all of your needs to refill more slowly. Get your needs into an overall excellent state to shrug off the effects.
Those jungle toxins have found their way into {0.SimFirstName}. Find some Bone Dust and trade it for an antidote quick.
The heat of the jungle is rising inside of {0.SimFirstName}. Keep a fire extinguisher handy because spontaneous combustion is likely.
This curse is causing visions of food everywhere, but none of it is edible. Satisfying your craving for Selvadoradian cuisine could help.
This curse is causing visions of Pancakes, and Bob, everywhere. Satisfying your craving for light, fluffy, golden brown pancakes could help.
This curse is causing visions of food everywhere, but none of it is edible. Satisfying your craving for Selvadoradian cuisine could help.
The Omisca really knew how to write amazing folk tales. That tale has {0.SimFirstName} energized!
This curse is causing overwhelming sadness. Work hard and become extremely happy to dispel this curse.
This curse is causing {0.SimFirstName} to have wild mood swings. Get back to a very happy mood to dispel this curse.
This curse is causing overwhelming sadness with a chance of lightning. Work hard to become very happy again to dispel this curse.
Popular for centuries (and easily lasting as long) this simple stone style supported many a grand building.
Sometimes the oldest techniques work (and look) the best. There is no denying the striking, classic look this ledge provides.
The wood is thick and hardy and has been well treated to ward of pests and weathering. This fencing should last for quite some time.
Brackish certainly isn't pleasant sounding nor very inviting. But it just means it has more salt than fresh water, but not as much as the ocean. It's not for drinking, but swimming in it is fine!
Ahhh so relaxing. Who doesn't like a nice, hot spring dip? And they're great all year round; not just in the spring.
It is amazing what can be accomplished with even the most basic of tools. Sims have been doing this for centuries!
At first glance this frieze seems simple and straight. But one is rewarded upon closer inspection with an array of magnificent details.
Archaeology is a fast, competitive, on the move science. This work bench was designed to keep up with scientists in the field or those working from home.
Hey! This is a hidden object. How did you find it! Oh well, fine. It provides some cool mood lighting.
Hey! This is a hidden object. How did you find it! Oh well, fine. It provides some cool mood lighting.
Hey! This is a hidden object. How did you find it! Oh well, fine. It provides some cool mood lighting.
Hey! This is a hidden object. How did you find it! Oh well, fine. It provides some cool mood lighting.
Not only beautiful, but this design is incredibly functional and funnels rain down and away from the base. Perfect for wet weather hot spots.
Not only beautiful, but this design is incredibly functional and funnels rain down and away from the base. Perfect for wet weather hot spots.
Why would you ever want a box of flies? If you’ve encountered the Selvadoradian Plasma Bat, you know why. Toss in the general direction of nearby bats to cause a distraction.
Charming. Elegant. Stately. All adjectives that jump to mind when seeing these lovely balconies clinging to and jutting from the sides of their buildings.
This wooden bar has been meticulously hand carved with a beautifully patterned and adorned rustic metal foot bar. This bar is aged and elegant.
When you've got to go, you've got to go. Even if you're in the middle of the jungle. Luckily you can escape the outdoor jungle to take care of your business in peace.
It's a Jungle in Here Bathroom
A fantastic way to relax and get clean. This tub was also designed to reverberate with deep bass notes if struck while empty.
A simple, yet sturdy wooden frame is the basis for this quintessential Selvadoradian bed. But the real treats are the vibrant, colorful sheets that playfully decorate this lovely bed of dreams.
A simple, yet sturdy wooden frame is the basis for this quintessential Selvadoradian bed. But the real treats are the vibrant, colorful sheets that playfully decorate this lovely bed of dreams.
By: MJ Agger\n\nLearn to tell the difference between ancient clay pots and someone's broken plates.
By: Brandon Rush\n\nSelecting the incorrect brush could lead to millions of years worth of damage.
Archaeology Vol 1: Tiny Brushes and You
By: D.E. Vo\n\nOut in the field and in desperate need of a clothesline? Take another look at your trusty bullwhip.
Archaeology Vol 2: 101 Uses for a Bullwhip
Don't stop, drop, and roll. This foam provides all the oxygen deprivation you need without all the rolling around. CAUTION: Children cannot use this. It contains chemicals hazardous to their health.
This simple solution will quickly and completely remove the grime from your body and leave you feeling fresh and clean. It's more than just water. We swear.
Perfect to keep kitchens clean and clutter-free, this cabinet hangs over its countertop counterpart to maximize space and reduce wasted motion.
This is a dirt clump. Perhaps something more lies within.
The keen eye of a knowledgeable observer will pick up subtle details that give this away as being a fake. There was no master craftsman behind the creation of this mask.
The Omisca dreamed of the ability to change their facial features at will. The best they could do was to use a Mask of Khaas to simulate a new set of facial features.
The Omisca had a saying. "If you can't change your face, paint it." That saying is represented with this Turquoise Mask of Khaas.
A beautiful mask. However, it was not very functional. Wearing this mask resulted in many neck injuries due to the sheer weight of this mask.

Yolotli, Chief of the First Season. Remembered forever as the greatest of the Omisca fighters. It is said he once fought off an assault of three dire chinchillas at once.

All prehistoric 3 toed creatures collectively agreed to evolve away from 3 toes. There were too many problems caused by the confusion between pointing and crude gestures.

Simple and straightforward, this counter puts function first and is incredibly efficient in its design. Solid counter top materials, industrial handles, and a sturdy frame that holds it all together make this the counter of choice for many Selvadoradian culinary experts.
A ancient carved relic base that reminds a Sim how chaos is a small part of every plan.
A ancient wooden relic base carved to remember the role of death in the natural cycle that every Sim takes part in.

The hieroglyph carved into this relic represents the Watcher. In the Omiscan origin myth, the Watcher emerged from the darkness to control chaos. The myth implies that the Omisca people would not live their lives if not being watched by the watcher.
This relic top is a carving of Zazatototl. The parrot spirit of storytelling.
When Zazatototl weaved stories of chaos Sims would need to be wary. Emotional swings, frightening deaths, and the struggle to satisfy basic needs of survival would be common themes.

This bright, cheery table is perfect to house all your wares for sale. Stock up, tend, PROFIT!
With the passage of time, age destroys all. Even the most beautiful wall can fall into dilapidated ruins given enough duration.
With the passage of time, age destroys all. Even the most beautiful wall can fall into dilapidated ruins given enough duration.
These aren't some flimsy swinging wooden doors you'd find in front of a saloon. No way. These are thick, solid doors made of the finest jungle wood and carved with loving, skilled hands.

This large arch supports several Sims entering shoulder to shoulder. These archways were probably built in large structures or various ancient temples rather than individual homes. But today you can do whatever you want with it! That's YOUR choice!
When a simple entrance won't suffice and something a little more striking is required. Make an impact by having guests pass through an ancient stone archway.
This door weighs a ton and is quite sturdy. It's made from a single piece of old hardwood and adorned with carvings and solid, iron handles.
Stones masterfully set in an arched format allow for passage through any wall. Easy to keep clean and incredibly durable, it's understandable why this specific style has been used for so long.
Stones masterfully set in an arched format allow for passage through any wall. Easy to keep clean and incredibly durable, it's understandable why this specific style has been used for so long.
Made popular in the mines of the 1800s these archways are super simple to construct and cheap to boot. But of course that's totally chic now (and so it's no longer cheap).

Typically hand carved and sourced from local materials this particular dresser is incredibly common in the Selvadoradian community. Some parents even use this as a hope chest for their children, who take the piece with them when they leave the nest.
Packed full of more energy per ounce than any other liquid. A great item to take on long hikes.
This bubbly drink removes the ill effects of one too many encounters with electricity.
This antidote can be used to cure a case of poisoning. Just chug it and you'll feel better. Just a warning though, it tastes awful if you're not really poisoned.
All the height of an indoors fireplace without the need of any pesky walls. Well, you can add walls if you want. We won't judge.
The beautiful Guzmania Pollenis flower is treasured by the people of Selvadorada. It is invaluable as a diversion for all forms of stinging hornets and bees.
The GCRE is a compact and nutritious grilled cheese sandwich for an on-the-go explorer. Use now or in 100 years. It will taste the same.
The temples of the ancient past had fountains that looked just like this. Maybe. Perhaps. We don't really know for sure, but this is the best guess using the most current information about the past.
The design is reminiscent of the classic 50's refrigerators of the past, but with a brushed metal exterior for a wholly modern take. Oh yeah, and it totally keeps perishables from perishing.
Avocados are delicious vegetables! Er... delicious fruits? Well whatever the correct classification it sure is good on toast!
Black Beans are super nutritious and good for Sims. Additionally, they are very versatile and can be used in a wide range of dishes.
These berries instill a sense of confidence in a Sim. Eat a bunch and you’ll get the guts for the most dangerous social maneuvers.
These berries will get a Sim moving! Full of vim and vigor, nothing else gets you energized so quickly. And they're delicious to boot! A win-win!
Be very careful around these berries. They will set your heart aflutter and can cause immediate flirtiness. Be aware of nearby Sims when consuming this fruit.
A quick handful of these berries will focus a Sim like a laser beam! Great for snacking during homework or when you just want to be able to concentrate.
Happy little berries make for a happy little Sim. Just pop one in your mouth and try not to smile. I dare you.
Writer's block? Struggling to solidify that spark of a great idea? Fear not, because around this fruit you're a bite away from a mouthful of inspiration.
These yummy berries are squishy and juicy. One taste will remind Sims of their childhood and cause playful tendencies.
This bush has the propensity to grow like wild vines if properly cared for.

This tree swirls with mysterious energy. The fruit from this tree is purported to trigger a range of emotional responses from the Sims who eat them.

You don't know anything about BBQ if you don't know about barrel meat. Throw it on the grill. Hit it low and slow to get all the juices going. The barrel holds and transfers the heat consistently. Get ready for your mouth to water!

If the bright glow of a candle does not suffice to fill the darkness void then how about six? This chandelier will blast you with righteous light. Better illumination through volume! That's a saying, right?
The base of this lamp is hand carved from locally sourced wood from Selvadorada and the shade features several local patterns. Find the look that best suits your home and pick one up today!
This rusting lantern is definitely showing its age. The bright light it still emits is a testament to its sturdiness and quality. It's definitely well made.
Surrounded by a beautifully gilded sheet of metal, a single light emits from within this sconce. It harkens back to bygone era where delicate details created form as sought out as function.
Think of the piece of bread you could butter with this thing! It may also be good for clearing a path through the jungle.
This makeshift market stall has been fitted with a functional kitchen to create all the wonderful jungle foods you know and love.
With this magical reflection device, gaze upon the glory of thine own face surrounded by rich brass studs. You stud you.
A doorway to the Natural Pools.

This pedestal is made from the ruins of the deep jungle temples. It's been ruined from the ravages of time, but it surprisingly has not yet been completely ruined. Perhaps the ancient Sims overlooked this stone.
Dr. Parker developed 8 scientifically proven defenses against those with 8 legs and up to 8 eyes. These defenses have now been transformed into this handy spray.
Super cooled ingredients extinguish the aggression of certain heat-creating Selvadoradian insects, allowing you to avoid searing irritation.
This powder spray provides an electrical grounding which directs any shocking Selvadoradian insects away from your vital bits.
Dust from ancient bones found in an Omiscan Temple.
These vines hang magically in the air. Does it make any sense? No. But you're cheating to see them and is that cool? Not really. So why don't we just forgive each other and move on?
This grass isn't really a cactus, but is commonly confused for one. It thrives in a variety of conditions and can be found as easily in the backyard as in the deep jungle.
This plant is native to tropical climates. There are many different varieties of this plant, but all share the same common traits - natural resistance to drought and extreme weather conditions.
This grass isn't really a cactus, but is commonly confused for one. It thrives in a variety of conditions and can be found as easily in the backyard as in the deep jungle.

Canna plants should be located where they will have strong visual impact. Most Cannas are tall and need to be placed at the back of a bed, but there are some Sims that prefer to plant at the front of the border. Really, there's no wrong way to plant it.
These clumps of grass have been left to grow wild and have risen almost waist high.
It's a Fern plant. It grows on the ground. Yup, that's where the name came from. Really stretching the wings of imagination here.
The Jalapa plant grows deep in the jungles of Selvadorada. With bright green leaves and varied, colorful flowers this ground cover looks quite beautiful with very little upkeep.
This large patch of fern contains very fine fronds and has spread quickly along the ground. It doesn't look too thick though and should not impede Sims' progress.

This plant is totally made out of cheese and tastes delicious. Try it. Okay okay, that was an outright lie. It's called a Swiss Cheese Plant, because its interesting leaves have holes and cuts throughout it.

Featuring the latest natural technology, this open air model gives the user a sense of freedom never before found in an outdoor toilet. Sure, some say it just looks like a bush to soil, but we feel it's a canvas to express yourself!
This plant thrives indoors, but its soil must be constantly moist. It prefers partial shade, but it's pretty hardy and should survive anywhere you put it.
It's hard to believe, but these three plants are closely related to each other and can usually be found growing close together in dense, vegetative environments.
It's a Fern plant. It hangs down. So you know, that's where the name came from. It wasn't a huge stretch. Cool plant though. Cool plant.
The flowers of this ivy plant commonly look like cute little lobster claws. Haters call them false bird-of-paradise. Totally uncalled for and petty.
Oh noes! Is the little Willow sad? No? Then why is it weeping? What did you do!?

Oh the adventures this Willow plant will embark upon - finding a hero to accept the baby of destiny and stopping the evil queen and her army while still making friends with scoundrels and tiny creatures along the way!
Great for hallways and small to medium sized rooms, this rug is a great way to bring the culture and charm of Selvadorada to any space.
The bright colors really pop and the patterns add a whimsy and charm unique to this region. The hardest part is finding a room big enough to lay this down.
Although its actual meaning has been lost over the centuries many Sims have their own theories regarding what these calendar-like circles represent.

Madre Cosecha helped the people settle Selvadorada during a time of great famine. Her long lost recipe of Grillos Achocolatados gave the founding settlers strength.\n\nArchaeologists also note that the Giant Omisca Cricket seems to have gone extinct during this great famine.

These vases are always seen paired together, never apart. Local myth tells the story of an enchanted prince transformed into vase alongside his forbidden love so that they could always be together. The details have been forgotten, but I'm sure it was a lovely tale.
Ruins of rubble? Are you really ready to release and resize the ruins remainder on the road or would you rather reign in your rage and respect the relative reminder of relaxing recreation?
This pillar is humongous! And so heavy! How did it get moved? Why? So many questions...
This pillar is humongous! And so heavy! How did it get moved? Why? So many questions...
This incredibly old vase has remained remarkably intact and preserved. What's inside? It could be anything? Even another vase!
This old vase relic is crumbling and worn. There seems to be some sort of bone fragments mixed into the sediment inside. How was this obtained?! It should be in a museum!

These are my jars. There are many like it, but these are mine. My jars are my best friend. I must master them as I must master my life. Without me, my jars are useless. Without my jars, I am useless. So buy these jars, amirite?
Once the solemn guardian of sacred relics, this sentry is now the perfect addition for a multitude of holiday and party decorations.
The carving of Zazatototl reminds the Omiscan people of the importance of storytelling and history.
The carving of Balampalsoh reminds the Omiscan people to treasure surprise and the unexpected events of life.
The carving of Totecallama reminds the Omiscan people to keep a firm defense up. Misfortune can befall the Sim who is not prepared.

The carving of the Lotus reminds the Omiscan people to stop and smell the flowers. Unless those flowers are full of stinging bugs, or poisonous snakes, or biting bats. Come to think of it, skip the flowers.
This ancient stone section of wall comes from the deep jungle recesses of Selvadorada. This particular section is not actually from there as it's a reproduction of the original.
A simple eco solution in providing weather protection.
Why use a normal chest when you can store your belongings in a treasure chest?! Brightly adorned and painted, this treasure chest sure feels like it has been around for quite some time.
Why use a normal chest when you can store your belongings in a treasure chest?! Is it a real treasure chest or a knock-off replica? Either way, it's the coolest chest around!

Decorate your pond or pool with the freshest of algae. This algae is always having fun and making new friends. Don't waste your time with those other nerdy Algae Clumps that are always doing math.
If normal Water Lilies symbolize deep spirituality and all that jazz then Giant Water Lilies must symbolize crazy extreme levels.
The skeletal assistant performed their duties admirably and left quite an impression. What was his, I mean her, um... what was its name again?
This broken section of ancient ruins probably used to be part of a wall or pedestal structure. Now it's the perfect conversation starter.

Back in the day these baskets were used during harvest season and were notorious for quickening the food spoilage process. That's probably why it's just used as a decoration now. What a terrible fruit basket.
Silk Flowers were not available to the Omisca. If they wanted a flower centerpiece without cutting fresh flowers daily then they had to carve one from stone themselves.
This vase painstakingly recreates the style of the ancient jungle civilization of the past. Filled with various twigs and branches this piece adds a lovely natural touch to any table setting.
Bougainvillea. Such a rich and interesting sounding word. Bougain Villea. Bogain Villa. Bogan Veeya. Uh oh. The name was said so many times it seems weird and wrong now. But really pretty still.

Carefully excavated, restored, pieced together and then framed. All this to give you a interesting talking point during your next dinner party.

This large decorative sign proudly displays a common Selvadoradian symbol found in many homes. Its exact meaning differs from Sim to Sim, but it generally represents good will and tidings to all travelers.

"The Watchers work to create the world. They take pieces of themselves. They take the light from within themselves and create suns. They take the darkness from within themselves and create night skies."\n\n-Excerpt from the Omisca Origin Myth
"The Watchers do not tell time as Sims do. Their time is longer, larger, unending. A Sim’s time in the world must end. As with one, so with all."\n\n-Excerpt from the Omisca Regeneration Myth

"In the darkness, there is chaos.

In the chaos is everything, and so it continues for generations and generations, chaos from chaos until the time when The Watcher emerges from the chaos. The Watcher controls the chaos and is also controlled by the chaos."

-Excerpt from the Omisca Origin Myth

"Death, a being of bones, who roams the world and brings Sims from their life to their death. Now, when a Sim dies, his heart is absorbed by Death and brought to the sun, where the Watchers store the energy they need for creation. With each Sim that is born they grab a pinch of sun and put it into the newborn heart, renewing the cycle once more."\n\n-Excerpt from the Omisca Death Myth
"The Watcher is light and dark, good and evil, fire and water, life and death. The Watcher is everything."\n\n-Excerpt from the Omisca Origin Myth

"But soon, the Watchers found this system unreasonable. The world was covered with Sims. The Sims could barely move about without bumping into one another. There was never enough food or beds or happiness to go around. The sun was shrinking with the energy that went into so much creation."\n\n-Excerpt from The Omisca Death Myth

"While the Sims may remember nothing of the previous worlds, The Watcher remembers them all, learns from them all. With each new world the Watcher divides into more Watchers, is able to create more Sims, smarter Sims, greater worlds.

This has all been and will forever be again."

-Excerpt from the Omisca Regeneration Myth
"The Watchers create trees and flowers, love and meanness, cooking and swimming."\n\n-Excerpt from the Omisca Origin Myth
"This has all been and will forever be again."\n\n-Excerpt from the Omiscan Regeneration Myth
"And so, from the parts of themselves that decay and renew, they create Death."\n\n-Excerpt from the Omisca Death Myth

"There comes a time when the curiosity of the Watchers is sated, when the world has run its course. Then do the Watchers collapse and 1,000 Watchers become The Watcher once more and the world collapses into chaos."\n\n-Excerpt from the Omisca Rengeneration Myth
"The Watcher divides until The Watcher is 10 Watchers, 100 Watchers, 1,000 Watchers."\n\n-Excerpt from the Omisca Origin Myth

"When Sims were first created, the Watchers argued amongst themselves on whether the Sims should be eternal like the Watchers themselves or whether they should walk about the world for a time and then be no more. At first, the Watchers who wished for Sims like themselves won out, and Sims lived and lived for as long as they were able, except for the few exceptions when one may have been taken by the water or the dangerous plants of the world."\n\n-Excerpt from the Omisca Death Myth

Sourced from old wood found deep in the Jungle this shelving unit is cheap, but very sturdy.
There is a hidden image for you to find as you gaze off into space during those long cold showers.

Welcome to the Selvadorada Jungle. It's full of fun and amusement. There's everything you could want; find what you need. But beware poison disease. Don't let your Sim get brought to their kna kna kna kna knees.
Welcome to the Jungle Base Camp Sign
This luxurious sink is beautifully hand-carved and meticulously detailed. The round glass basin adds a modern touch to an otherwise timeless look.

Extremely functional, the wide basin allows great access to the water flow without any pesky counter splashing. This sink is almost industrial in quality and will take quite the beating before wear will show.
What a good looking stool! The generous curves, fine leather padding, and smoothly sanded wood all combine into a luxury stool fit for royalty.
This chair is sturdy and made for long term use. The crafters of Selvadorada certainly make furniture to last the ages. You certainly get what you pay for.
This uniquely designed chair has a look distinct to Selvadorada. The fine furniture makers have honed in their craft and knocked this one out of the park.
Perfect to set up on the patio and take in the crisp morning air. Grab a cup of coffee or tea and simply relax.
Sometimes you need a simple stool upon which to rest your tired bones. Nothing fancy needed; no cushions, no pretentious designs. Just a simple wooden stool.
The Sims of Selvadorada love bright, dramatic splashes of color and this piece showcases the style beautifully. Sure to add a touch of warmth to any environment.
Despite it's simplistic shape the interesting designs and bold accent colors set this bench apart from others. Truly unique and lovely furniture for all your living needs!
Perfect alongside the other Selvadoradian pieces, this sofa is vibrant, cheery, and gracefully represents the culture from which it originated.
This wall-mounted stereo is intended for use at community venues. It plays Latin Pop music which is sure to get your hips moving.
This wall-mounted stereo is intended for use at community venues. It plays all the traditional Latin sounds.

Classic? Modern? What is it (besides confusing)? Well, it's the best of both worlds! Built with the form and function of the past in mind, but with all the improved modern day amenities, this stove can almost cook the food itself...and look great doing it.

The wood is so gorgeous you'll never let a Sim place coffee on this coffee table. Coaster! You're going to need a lot of coasters! Because if, by Sims, the little ones spill anything on this table there is going to be a wrath!
The star of the show here is the gorgeous single wooden plank that the whole piece is built around. The quality of wood and love displayed in its craftsmanship is clear for all to see.

Sometimes frivolous decorations, bells, and whistles are completely unnecessary. This table focuses on featuring the beauty of natural wood in its best possible form. The result is an incredibly focused design that fits in almost any household aesthetic.
Simple and structurally straightforward, this table still has an air of grace and sophistication about it. It would look as good next to a luxury sofa as it would in a new couple's starter home.

Although great care and detail has gone into the design of this table, it's the wood that is the star of the show. Made from reclaimed fallen jungle trees the planks come in many different colors and grains. A very personalized and unique piece.

Perfect for containing all those unsightly bathroom odds and ends, the look of this table is somewhat unique to the normal style of Selvadorada. While it features traditional wooden materials, the door designs and handle are somewhat at odds with normal sensibilities.
Sometimes simple is the way to go. It's amazing what a lovely overall look a minimalist approach can provide. The slightly rough and imperfect presentation translates to a slick, perfect style,
With far more embellishments than its rustic Selvadoradian counterpart, the curves and metal attachments set this piece apart from traditional Selvadorada stylings.
Even when deep, deep in the unexplored vastness of the jungle you've got to be able to place your lunch on a flat surface. This table will do the trick!
Deep in the Bush Picnic Table
Helps take just a little off the top of those tricky woodworking projects.
This doll is a stunningly accurate re-creation of ancient toys found in Omiscan ruins. It's soft, snuggly, and makes a great souvenir for budding young archaeologists!
A doorway into the Temple, without the deadly barriers.
Surprise! Enjoy the crumbly gold or someone's limb!
Don't upset Omlic. He may have been rescued from the jungle, but he still has feelings.
It's like a slot machine, but if you lose, it kills you!
Spoiler: the last element is you!
The warriors of old are still guarding the Temple's hidden secrets.
These are really hardy trees that thrive in the sun and moisture. Its giant leaves can stretch to over eleven feet long and several varieties proliferate the jungle areas.

Did you know that the wood from this type of tree is commonly used to make bows for string instruments like the violin? This dense wood is now an endangered species so it really shouldn't be used as a natural resource anymore.

This medium sized tree has long, multiple-pinnated fronds that grow in coils and uncurl as they grow. They are a visibly unique tree, can transplant easily, and thrive in a variety of weather conditions,

This is a giant tree! Those only familiar with a Ficus in houseplant form are in for a surprise. This is a tropical tree known for producing figs and the ability to be processed into a variety of industrial products (like latex).
Nothing says jungle like the iconic Palm tree. Sometimes they grow alone and other grow in clumps. In this case, Ivy has been creeping up the trunk of this tree for some time now.
Open slits in this stone window allow natural light to directly enter; no glass needed. But don't worry. The window wasn't hurt when the glass was removed. It was paneless.

This ancient panel ruin shows just how early Sims decorated their temples and special buildings. It's pretty cool that historians have been able to uncover these styles to be replicated in modern day shops.

Okay, to be perfectly honest, calling this a window is extremely generous. We all agree on that. It's much closer to being a hole in the wall than a window. But no one wants to hurt its little feelings so just let it have this one.
It's way too cold and drab to be opening shutters right now (and maybe a little privacy is desired). It's nice to have them and all, but keep those shutters closed up tight right now.
A small square wooden window that is thrust open wide to allow entrance to nature's cool touch.
A small square wooden window that is thrust open wide to allow entrance to nature's cool touch.
Full of South Simerican charm, this traditional wooden frame houses playful glass panes that add a charm to the layout.
Open the shutters and let there be light. Lean over the railing and breathe in that fresh air.
Caution: In cases of poisoning please consult with local Sims for antidotes.

It's important to prepare for the many dangers lurking in the jungle with the right Adventure Gear. Check the marketplace vendors to see what helpful items they are offering. The selection is always changing so check back often.
This can't be used when you're already in water.
You donated an artifact to the museum!
Yeah... you should really do this yourself.
I can see the adaptation and development of Omiscan sculpting methods in this piece. The artist took it and made it their own.
This painting uses paint colors commonly used by Selvadoradian artists. Their palette is derived from the Omiscan relics excavated and cleaned up by archaeologists in the Belomisia jungle.
The use of sandpaper in this piece really provides some grit.
The shapes and colors in this piece fit the established Omiscan formula for bathroom signage. I wonder if the artist knew this about the pieces that influenced his or her own art.
I can see the classic inspiration in this work. The inspiration from beavers, woodpeckers, and termites is front and center.
Everything that is old is new again and this piece proves that. This style has been done before and will be done again.
Wood was one of the original crafting materials sculptors would use. Unfortunately not many pieces survive the centuries. The sculpting techniques have survived and are in display in this piece.
The sculpt here is reminiscent of the decorative reliefs which appear in Omiscan temples.
If I squint my eyes I can just make out the Selvadoradian influences in this painting. This artist must've visited the Omiscan ruins while perfecting their eye for colors.

{0.SimFirstName}'s expert knowledge of the Omiscan culture and the techniques of its master craftsmen have helped {M0.him}{F0.her} determine this is a fake. It is subtle. Only a trained eye could spot the difference.
After careful analysis {0.SimFirstName} has determined this artifact is genuine. Further analysis will allow {0.SimFirstName} to continue to hone {F0.her}{M0.his} archaeology Skill.
{0.SimFirstName} needs an Archaeology Table for this.

Sims with higher Gardening Skill clear faster and are less likely to hurt their hands. Or purchase a machete at the Marketplace.
This path is sealed shut and cannot be opened on this trip! Perhaps next vacation it'll open?
{0.SimFirstName}'s hands are still stinging from clearing the thorny vines from the last obstacle! {M0.He's}{F0.She's} going to need a little break before trying again.
Clears the path faster and without hurting one's hands, but the machete may be lost.
{0.SimFirstName} was forging through some thick vines a little too enthusiastically when {M0.his}{F0.her} machete flew out of {M0.his}{F0.her} hands and was lost forever in the thick jungle.
Check back in half a day or so!

Tell a Folktale about a Jaguar and a Skunk
Tell a Folktale about a Man with a Big Hat

Thank you! That antidote tasted wretched but it really did the trick. I'm feeling healthy again.
Take this antidote that I made with the bone dust you provided.

You need to bring me some bone dust if you want me to create a antidote.\n\nIf you don't have any bone dust I have heard a jungle named online retailer sells the antidote if you have access to a computer. It won't be cheap.

Plasma bats swoop down from the jungle canopy at all hours of the day. Scratches, bites and guano will ruin your day.\nPack a plasma bat bait box to distract them. If you have a high enough fitness you may outmaneuver them.

A while ago, I made my way across the rope bridge. That broken dam may have caused some trouble, but it created a breathtaking waterfall. It would be a great place to take a special someone for a romantic moment.
Numerous spiders and bees call the jungle their home, and they don’t like visitors!\nIf you are logical enough you can step carefully through the jungle and avoid these dangerous pests.
Stock up on adventure gear before you set out. There are many natural dangers to overcome on top of taking care of your basic needs.

Excursions into the Jungle can take all day and all night. Make sure to stock up on supplies like the Grilled Cheese Ready to Eat or a can of Liquid Rush. When you get hungry or are low on energy you will be glad you have them.
There are tales of a grand Omiscan temple deep in the jungle. The rumors of treasure are tempting, but the amount of danger has kept me from searching for myself.

There are many things in the Jungle that can poison you. We have developed a cure, but it requires bone dust to make.\nIf you find yourself poisoned, bring a pile of bone dust to any local to trade for a poison antidote.

Not too long ago a pilot wandered out of the jungle. She saw what looked like ancient artifacts in the soil near the plane crash. If you are an ambitious archaeologist you should search for that plane.
I'd advise carrying a machete if you plan to explore deep into the jungle. Nothing is better at cutting through the undergrowth.
There are some great fishing spots in the jungle if you can find them. Watch out for the snappers. In this jungle you may be the bait!

From time to time an unfortunate Selvadoradian gets cursed. We know what to do and I’m going to share that tip with you. Visit the Statue of Madre Cosecha in front of the Cantina. With a generous donation the curse can be removed.

My uncle’s neighbor’s sister’s cousin told me there is a cursed skeleton that walks the grounds of the old Omiscan Temple. Real or not, the possibility makes me think twice about searching for the temple.
The Omiscans built traps into their temple. They didn’t intend for the traps to keep everyone out. If you’ve honed your mind and body you can easily get passed some of the traps.
One of the rumors going around is that there are relics that work as a combination key to open temple gates. That sounds preferable to activating the wrong trigger on a trap.
Fire flies and lighting bugs can ruin any trek into the deep jungle. If you’ve taken the time to learn about our culture you might learn how to pacify those insects.
There is a myth that the ancient people cultivated trees with mood altering fruit. Finding truth in that myth would be quite the botanical discovery.
Everyone knows that the Omiscan people were advanced builders and designed mechanisms mistaken for magic. Some people even say the Temple itself changes to confuse intruders.
Over the years a few Omiscan relics have been found. They seem to emanate a magical power. If you find more of these pieces perhaps you can combine them and discover their secrets.

From the edges of the village you can see a ruined platform jutting out from the mountain. The views from that spot must be magnificent and inspiring. If you find a way to it make sure to take in the view.

My grandparents used to sneak off to an old Omiscan pool deep in the jungle. They said it was once used by royalty! The paths are blocked by overgrown vines now. If you find it while exploring perhaps you should take a dip.
Learn about History of Local Goods

{0.SimFirstName} has cursed {1.SimName} with Greedy Needs! {M1.He}{F1.She} will need to take of {M1.his}{F1.her} needs more often now.
You already have a skeleton serving you.
Alexandrite is composed of Firaxium, Goobleck, and Oxylin in balanced amounts.
Amazonite is composed of the elements Crytacoo, Melacoo, and Sealium.
This antidote can be used to cure a case of poisoning. Just chug it and you'll feel better. Just a warning though, it tastes awful if you're not really poisoned.
Enjoy the sounds and stylings of traditional Latin music. Keep those ears open.
This station plays Latin Pop. All. Day. Long. Everyday!
Place an Unauthenticated Artifact on an Archaeology Table. Click the Artifact and select Authenticate Artifact.\n\nAuthenticate Artifact is available at Archaeology Skill Level 3.
Excavate {1.Number} Dig Piles or Excavation Sites
These sites can be found in the Jungle of Selvadorada.\n\nClick on a Dig Pile or Excavation Site and select Excavate.
Find a Dig Pile in the world of Selvadorada. Click on the Dig Pile and then select Establish Excavation Site.\n\nThis interaction is available at Archaeology Skill Level 6.
Find and Authenticate {1.Number} Excellent Quality Artifacts

Clumps of Dirt and Unauthenticated Artifacts can be found in Dig Piles or Excavation Sites.

Place an Unauthenticated Artifact on an Archaeology Table. Click on it, and then select Authenticate Artifact.

Check the artifact's tooltip to find out if it is Poor or Excellent quality.
Click on another Sim and select Give Archaeology Lecture under Friendly.\n\nDon't bore the crowd.
Archaeology Skill can be gained by Excavating Dig Piles, Uncovering and Authenticating Artifacts, Refining Crystals, Analyzing Collectibles, and by Reading Skill Books.
Archaeology Skill can be gained by Excavating Dig Piles, Uncovering and Authenticating Artifacts, Refining Crystals, Analyzing Collectibles, and by Reading Skill Books.
Archaeology Skill can be gained by Excavating Dig Piles, Uncovering and Authenticating Artifacts, Refining Crystals, Analyzing Collectibles, and by Reading Skill Books.
This interaction is available at Level 4 Archaeology Skill.\n\nIn Selvadorada, click on the ground outside and select Survey for Dig Pile.
Dirt Clumps can be found while Excavating Dig Piles.\n\nPlace a Dirt Clump on an Archaeology Table. Click on the Dirt Clump and then select Uncover.
Write a Good Archaeology Skill Book
Click on a Computer. Under Write, select Write Skill Book then select Guidebook to Archaeology.
Click on an assembled Mystical Relic in your Sims' inventory. Select 'Activate' to activate on your Sim, or choose 'Activate On...' and select another Sim to activate on.

Click on either a Mystical Relic Top or Bottom in the Sim's inventory and select 'Fuse With...' Then click on the combined relic and select 'Insert Crystal...'\n\nRelic pieces can be found in temple treasure chests.
Find a Craft Sales Table in the open air market and buy any local item for sale.\n\nThe market can be found near the Cantina in the Puerto Llamante district of Selvadorada.
Omiscan Treasures can be found in Rare Omiscan Treasure Chests deep within Temples. Seek out Treasure Chests until you find one of the golden frogs or calendar plates.
Order and eat a local dish from a Selvadoradian Food Stall or from cooking those dishes at home.
Find your way to an Omiscan Temple. Click on a Temple Trap and select Examine.
Find an Area off the Path
Travel deep into the Belomisia Jungle. Clear and pass through the Path Obstacles to discover hidden areas off the main path as you trek towards the Omiscan Temple.

Prepare for Natural Dangers by purchasing Adventure Gear from Selvadoradian merchants and having them in the Sim's inventory when Natural Dangers strike.\n\nFor example, having a Guzmania Pollenis Flower will defend against jungle bees.
These colorful Treasure Chests can be found deep within the Omiscan Temples.\n\nWhen you have located a Treasure Chest, click on the Treasure Chest and select 'Open Treasure Chest'.
To Increase Selvadoradian Culture skill, use local socials like Chat about Local Sights, Ask about the Jungle, and Discuss Local Heritage. Also try Selvadoradian foods or view the town statue.
To Increase Selvadoradian Culture skill, use local socials like Chat about Local Sights, Ask about the Jungle, and Discuss Local Heritage. Also try Selvadoradian foods or view the town statue.
Click on the statue and select the View interaction. The statue is located near the Cantina "El Arbol del Jaguar" in the Puerto Llamante district of Selvadorada.
The ancients of Selvadorada certainly added mysterious details to the natural pools found deep in the jungle.
Firm yet gentle, this stair railing will always be there to support you. It's nice to have something to catch you.
Where to go, what to eat, and how many pairs of socks you should pack.
This book is a guide for other Sims to learn Archaeology Skill.
Brew a Remedy of the Ancients
This lot cannot be edited while on vacation, but you can get supplies at the Marketplace.
Enjoy learning about the Selvadorada culture, or explore the jungle's hidden secrets. But be prepared! It won't be an easy trek through the jungle.
This is a very common jungle theme found on virtually every home there. Efficient and sturdy, it's not hard to see why it's so popular.
{0.SimFirstName} has finished {M0.his}{F0.her} time as a mystical undead servant and will return to a peaceful rest.

Find a Dig Pile or Excavation Site and select Excavate.

Study an Object for Historical Insights
Select a painting, sculpture, or woodworking object and select Study for Historical Insights.
Select terrain and survey for Dig Pile.
Dig up a dirt clump and Uncover it on the Archaeology Table.
Find a way to dispel the Curse of the Ancients before time runs out!
Dispel a Curse of Greedy Needs
Improve all of your Needs to dispel the Curse of Greedy Needs before time runs out!
Find a way to dispel your Marked For Death curse before time runs out!

Slot a refined crystal into a fused relic and select Activate.
Gather a relic top and a relic bottom and select fuse.
Click on a Selvadoradian Sim and select Ask about the Jungle. The locals of Selvadorada can provide information on the jungle.
Click on a Selvadoradian Sim and select Ask about the Omiscan Ruins Social from the Friendly Category.
Click on a Selvadoradian local and select Inquire about Local Myths, Discuss Local Heritage, or Chat about Local Sights from the Friendly.
